number.text: In this tutorial I'll show you what cube maps are in OpenGL and how you can use them to create skyboxes.

number.title: Cubemaps & Skyboxes.mp4
number.text: So what are cube maps? Well, there's simply another type of texture which holds 6 2D textures,

number.title: Cubemaps & Skyboxes.mp4
number.text: one for each side of a cube. When sampling a cube map, you specify a 3D vector instead of a 2D

number.title: Cubemaps & Skyboxes.mp4
number.text: one. This allows you to easily sample between all 6 sides of the cube. And since the coordinates

number.title: Cubemaps & Skyboxes.mp4
number.text: of the cube correspond to the sampling vectors, there's no need for UVs. The most common

number.title: Cubemaps & Skyboxes.mp4
number.text: uses for cube maps are what's fear texturing and skyboxes. So now let's code it in.

number.title: Cubemaps & Skyboxes.mp4
number.text: The first thing you need to do is to write out the cube vertices and indices.

number.title: Cubemaps & Skyboxes.mp4
number.text: Then we'll want to create a VIO, VBO and IBO just like in the first tutorials. Now let's create

number.title: Cubemaps & Skyboxes.mp4
number.text: an array with 6 strings that will hold the paths to the 6 images we'll be using for the skybox.

number.title: Cubemaps & Skyboxes.mp4
number.text: Then we want to create a cube map texture itself, just like any other texture,

number.title: Cubemaps & Skyboxes.mp4
number.text: except that where we put GL texture 2D before, we now put GL texture cube map.

number.title: Cubemaps & Skyboxes.mp4
number.text: Make sure to clump the texture in all 3 directions, since the texture is a cube,

number.title: Cubemaps & Skyboxes.mp4
number.text: therefore 3D. This clamping should prevent any seams from showing up.

number.title: Cubemaps & Skyboxes.mp4
number.text: And now we'll go over all 6 textures and read them using the SDB library,

number.title: Cubemaps & Skyboxes.mp4
number.text: putting them in the cube texture once we read them. Notice how I disabled a vertical flipping.

number.title: Cubemaps & Skyboxes.mp4
number.text: This is because unlike most textures in OpenGL, cube maps are expected to start in the top left

number.title: Cubemaps & Skyboxes.mp4
number.text: corner, not the bottom left corner. Also notice how I add I to GL texture cube map positive x.

number.title: Cubemaps & Skyboxes.mp4

number.text: Well, normally in OpenGL, the front is in the negative Z direction, but for cube maps,

number.title: Cubemaps & Skyboxes.mp4
number.text: the front is in the positive Z direction. That means that cube maps work in a left-handed system,

number.title: Cubemaps & Skyboxes.mp4
number.text: while most of OpenGL works in a right-handed system. This can be very confusing,

number.title: Cubemaps & Skyboxes.mp4
